The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course provided a good introduction to the properties of nanomaterials, the physics behind them, and their various applications.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Good range of topics covered, but not nearly enough depth and content for a graduate level course. Since the class is a graduate level class, I was expecting the professor to be an expert in the topic area, but it became clear that he was not. Towards the second half of the semester, the material petered out and we spent too much class time figuring out project logistics. Improve the course by spending more time on the fundamentals (don't be afraid to go through mathematical derivations and thermodynamics). Flesh out each of the topics more. Perhaps present recent publications. It would be helpful to prepare and share a syllabus with each class date and topic to be covered on that date, to help with class organization. Also, I don't think it's fair (or within GSAS policy) for the TA to grade projects/presentations/papers since these are qualitative assessments.

There was a wealth of material, but it was presented in a generally effective manner. Each topic was discussed with a good amount of depth, without going into too much unnecessary detail. The range of topics was appropriate and broad enough to give a good general understanding of many properties and applications.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Perhaps. It will probably improve next time. Would be an okay introductory course for undergraduates.
I would definitely recommend this to anyone who plans to be working with nanomaterials, to get a good understanding of their properties, synthesis techniques, and characterization techniques.
